This functionality is used "all the time" here at NIST/JQI.  The problem it solves is that for max stability we never ever stop the experiment from cycling, but you generally don't want to repeat a batch of shots, just the last one that keeps the system warm and in a default state.

For the GUI: I don't favor an approach that adds clutter to the interface.  

* A different solution would be to have a check button like it is, repeat or not repeat, but on right click you have the option of selecting what the type of "repeat" occurs.  This would use the same context menu that Chris has written, but it would be activated on right click rather than always.

* In my own code I would use a QComboBox in this instance rather than a button.  I don't see what benefit the button gives, but I also don't care enough to press the point.

The point of the button was kind of like, you're either repeating or not, and you're either paused or you're not, and the pause button doesn't change to say "paused" when it's pressed it - the label on it says what it does when it's pressed in, not the current setting. So I was going for consistency with that, as well as the fact that comboxes are bigger and don't support the same style as the other buttons.

I had thought about the right-click option but it's not very discoverable, even with a tooltip. Maybe a small button to open a menu to select the mode would be better. Here's what it would look like

![:](data/bitbucket.org/repo/dR5qxr/images/2268943976-blacs_repeat.png)

And then the main button would just be a simple checkbutton again, either pressed in or not, and the icon on it would indicate which type of repeat mode had was set in the menu. Then we've achieved the goal of one-click turning on and off repeat for most people without cluttering the GUI much with more elements, and without having the option be too undiscoverable.

In the other pull request I will also move the delete button to the side of the shot queue where the moving buttons are, since it's more about the shots than the queue, and have it lose the text so it's just a tiny button like in the Spielman fork. This will save some real estate at the top of the queue so those buttons don't prevent you from dragging the slider to make the queue part of the GUI small.

I would suggest a set of 3 buttons, connected via a [`QButtonGroup`](http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/qbuttongroup.html) (one for each of the possible modes). You might not even need the text, just 3 icons  with tooltips (the existing 2 icons plus a new one that indicates a linear execution of shots). 

Personally I think we should change the pause button to indicate the current state as well, rather than what it is now (we had a bug report about this at one point but I think it probably died with the redmine tracker).  Although it would be important to ensure it could be toggled via the keyboard - i.e. spacebar - if it was turned into two separate buttons (one for play, one for pause...I guess it could just be a single button that change the text and icon when clicked though as well, but I think two buttons makes it more obvious what it is doing?)

I don't think that's a great idea - three buttons is a more complicated target than one button, which will be the normal state of affairs - JQI pretty much always has it in repeat-last mode and so would just be hitting that one toggle, use of this menu would be pretty rare. The icon on the button changes to show the mode that is in use (or will be in use once you press the button), so there's not much risk of confusion as to to which mode is set. The tooltip for the dropdown menu button says "select repeat mode". I'm pretty happy with it (and I've pushed it to this pull request, I'd made the changes before your comment), so let me know what you think, and maybe Shaun can weigh in as well.

I think the pause and repeat buttons are good having text since the text is a verb that says what happens when the button is checked. I was reading about this aspect of UI design earlier today, and came across this stack exchange post:

https://ux.stackexchange.com/questions/1318/should-a-toggle-button-show-its-current-state-or-the-state-to-which-it-will-chan

The top answer says this about toggle controls like these:

> The authors (and I think of these as an authority on the subject) presents two possible solutions: You should either spell the button's action out as a verb phrase (e.g., Switch to portrait mode, thereby sacrificing some of the saved space) or use some other technique entirely (e.g., two radio buttons).

We're using verbs - "pause", "repeat", rather than indicating the current state, which seems to be the least confusing option, if you're going to use toggles. Lyse violates this though by saying "analysis running", "analysis paused" with a "play" icon. That's pretty confusing. Maybe the bug report was about that?
